title: Lessons Learned: Experiences in other Sectors
segmentation: Hi thanks Maria.
So my name is Stephen Davey, unit research Manager and telecommunications Software Systems Group in water for the Institute of Technology.
We do have a lot of expertise in technologies related to cloud telecommunications systems and we're starting to look quite distinctly on data analytics and big data in particular.
Alot of our research projects would be focused on lots of different verticals, such as the communications element in lots of different verticals related to.
You know to these projects and data analytics is starting to become a very big issue and you know very important tool.
As Maria pointed out.
In trying to achieve, you know higher productivity in some of the areas that we work on.

So what I'm going to talk about for a couple of minutes is some of the you know the big projects that we've been working on recently and how we see that there's an angle of data analytics and big data that was involved in it and so many issues that we that we talked kind of a unique type project or kind of unique to that sector.
And I can explain in more detail.
So you know, big data is often kind of described.
As you know, these four vis volume, so that you know if you're trying to cope with large and large volumes of data into the terabytes.
You need you need particular different mechanisms then that that were there in the past.
You know, like different types of databases, different types of algorithms that are able to process the data a lot faster.
One of the RV's there is variability of the data.
So that means if you're taking data from lots of different sources and you're trying to make sense of it.
Denise, we have some processes in place to align the data together.
Try to match it up with each other so we can you learn something across all these kind of different datasets.
And the last one is velocity.
Velocity is how fast is the data being generated?
Help faster, nature.
Like you could look at Facebook for example.
The many people that are posting content, clicking on buttons.
That's generating volumes and volumes of very fast data that's coming into Facebook and they're trying to process it really quickly.
So does not the voter's, besides those previous.

There's lots of other attributes of big data that those TV's don't cover, and it really get when you get into the actual practical matter of trying to use big data to Troy tackle some practical problems you start to see what are those other elements.
I'm going to take in some experiences from transport, energy and kind of disaster situations.
And then I kind of summarize some of the lessons we've learned as well.
So let's say in transport and transport, then we had a recent project called Drive and essentially it's looking at the the issue of.
And it is becoming quite quite more common.
You're trying to, as a company, or you're offering this product where you can store it into your car.
And it's going to, you know, track your driving performance is going to track your speed of the car.
It's going to track.
You know all the different data that's connected car.
How you're handling are you breaking?
It would be almost be able to detect.
Has the car been in an accident?
It was a sudden change in velocity.
This data is is, you know, being pumped up to.
And the cloud has been processed by the company and the company is going to look at this data and this is, you know, quite private data to the driver of the car.
Because he you know he's quite concerned he would be quick and sort of who's going to get access to this data that I've I've put up.
So privacy is a big concern and privacy of of the data that you're generating.

I it's you know it's owned by a certain user, so the companies that are taking this data and processing it, they need to be cognizant of who owns the data and who's going to own the results of our after processing this data.
So for this company E drive what we were looking to develop was a solution where the motorist he was actively being.
He was actively able to control what data he could share with the company.
So if he, if he was willing to release more data or you know release, you know GPS data release date around handing in the car.
He was able to potentially unlock more benefits from the company.
So there was a trade off, but you also had to leave the balance in the hands of the the person that was generating that data.
So that's one of the lessons that we kind of learned from from transport, but I think that that could be murdered across a lot of other verticals as well.
Particularly, you know you can take it, for example in the home.
Let's say if you're buying a security solution in the home where.
You know all the motion sensors in your house.
All our data is being sent up to the cloud is being monitored by a company.

You want to make sure that you know the people that have access to that data that you will have still have some kind of control over when you want him to be able to use that data when they can use it.
I am.
So what were the lessons then?
Is the user is in control of their data?
And even if it's if it's fast, if it's variable.
If there's a lot of it.
And they still need to be in control of it.
So privacy of the data is a very big issue.
Especially when you're trying to commercialize some solutions in the area.
Experiences in the energy sector.
One of the one of the other projects we had which was called CECO.
Anne, it's looking at the enterprise, you know, and in particular vertical.
Potentially they they are able to provide a producer on air energy or they have a certain manufacturing process where they can.
They can time when the.
When do they want to use their energy?
When did he want to turn machinery on?

When do they want to set up a
And are in their manufacturing environment?

And the solution was there to try and allow these enterprises to understand how their load is flexible and understand how they can shift the different load in the enterprise at different times to maximize their use of water, renewable energy or energy.
That's that's currently at a cheap price.
So in the end, this in this way we were gathering, you know, the organizations to gather energy from lots of different enterprises.
And again it was able to kind of process essentially, so does so again, just that there's a lot of issues around that data.
Ham but what we also found was that.
Lots of different organizations are going to have lots of different types of sensors, lots of different.
No ways that they can control the load of new enterprise.
What might work for a refrigeration company, for example, wouldn't work for a paper manufacturing company because it's just very different load that they have.

So the solutions that we have to take back that's trying to process and understand the workload for each organization will have to be so much tailored for each on organization as well, so you know these kind of a general one algorithm suits all, not doesn't necessarily fit into every situation.
I am so that was one of the big one of the big lessons that we learned when we were trying to develop this system.

So in the end we're trying to develop quite a general system, could help lots of different organizations that had different kind of flexible load, but we had to take into consideration to varied variability, index, flexible load and inhaled, or capturing that information.
Another issue was that.
You know, let's say 1 enterprise was generating energy and essentially it could have the option to to sell it back to the grid, but instead it was another option that it could.
It could set it to its neighboring enterprise.
So this was, you know, the organization was getting this data in.
But the two organizations you know they could be competitors.
And even though it might steal them both on a commercial sense, decomposed reduce your energy bill.
They might necessarily want to share data.

So so have a clear processes in handling the data in place so that the two organizations would be comfortable in at least sharing some sharing information and off information that cobalt reduce their energy bills was important for that project as well.
I then experiences in and a disaster zone, so we run a project a couple of years ago called societies and societies about building communities of users that were using pervasive technologies.
So this was using a wearable computers using short range Wi-Fi to build different communities of users that were able to share some of the services that they would have.
So in in one of the trials that the project was can we use these technologies when, let's say you know in a disaster or search and rescue operation?
So with the search and rescue operation, what you'd have is just after an incident would happen.
One of the first steps is you need to do an assessment of the of the incident or disaster.
So in this situation this situation, you know team people is going on site, they want to get as much data in of what's actually happening on the ground.
You know how many people are injured?
Where are they?
What's the condition of the different infrastructure and they want to get all this data as fast as possible?
And there's lots of different ad hoc sources of this data that they need to bring in as well.
And what we found was obviously to be varying accuracy of so many data as well, and it could be looking at sources of data that would be almost like non traditional where we usually sources.
Ann wanted examples we had was, you know, at the for the you know, the earthquake that was in Japan, Japan and Fukushima.
There was a lot of search and rescue information that was actually being shared on Twitter and there was a platform that was.

You know Twitter isn't designed to be as an emergency solution for these people, but it was a good way of getting data shared across, you know, an infrastructure that typically you know you won't be able to get access to.
I wondered the challenges that we find is becausw, you know Twitter isn't designed to have guaranteed message delivery, it's it's.
It's kind of like it will eventually be delivered rather than it needs to be delivered now.

That's where we see just there's challenges in, you know, trying to use that type of technology even though even though it works, you know well in principle, it leaves yourself open if you depend on it, you know.
So it opens up.
Then the opportunity to develop these kind of systems or mechanisms.
In some systems like Twitter, for example, that can handle, you know emergency broadcasts of messages that that can be guaranteed and prioritized.
Sam so some of the lessons that we learned.
Is that you need to be able to gather in lots of data in from different sources to try and validate.
Some of the information you have, so you're getting GPS data in your getting people in.
Let's say someone's on the phone describing where they are that might, you know, reinforce the GPS data of where they are and all this data can be used to build a better picture of these.
You know disaster recovery areas.
Even 3 minutes.
Right?
So some similar lessons learned and this is, you know, looking back at some of those issues.
And of course there's a lot more lessons to be learned as well.
Processing processing of personal or commercial data or you know, especially if it's if it's big data and it has its own challenges till it needs to be.
Have some kind of control over from either the person or the businesses perspective.
You know from the person it's they want to make sure who's going to be looking at the process and results of this data for the company.
It's you don't want.
You don't want to make sure that your competitors can get access to some of the data that you've been generating.

And particularly in this business critical or or disaster recovery area, you want to be able to make decisions that are based on, you know, you know multiple sources of evidence, so you want to have some kind of validation process built into your summer mechanisms.
And then when dealing with many sources of data.
You know, typically this.
You know this is dealing with the variability of.
And taking different from the transportation is example.
You have many companies or have many people.
Many different types of vehicles and you need to align it all to give some clear direction of your device.
The data needs to be cleaned and it needs to be processed.
OK, so that's all from for me.
You know, if you want to catch up with me later about some of those projects free to catch me after after the session.
OK, thank you.
